column3: Who books this tour?
lance did it better

One of the most moving, motivating and powerful pieces I‚Äôve seen.
Mis respetos, que vivan los sue√±os, ni un paso atr√°s, Love Rapha.........

Someone sent me this when I was at a very low ebb I have terminal rare appendix cancer and I am mostly alone to deal with it.  Before my diagnosis I was cycling and hiking, love the outdoors and nature, love camping and just being.  Today I struggle to see sense in it all, my pain is increasing and I am unable to cycle or walk far and feel my life is over but now I have to suffer the pain to reach that end.  After reaching out on Facebook someone sent me this video, from this day forth I will watch this every day and I know it‚Äôll change my mindset. My cancer is incurable and now it‚Äôs a waiting game but I‚Äôm determined that my last breath will be taken doing what I love, cycling, walking and being with nature.  This video is my inspiration until my final breath Thank you for this great video and the truest words I‚Äôve heard in a long time. Hope is all I have left.
I always come back here to renew my motivation to ride.
üò≠
Your a inspiration for everyone out there. Thanks so much for sharing your story.

I was given six months to live at 37 with multiple myeloma.  I had breast cancer at 30. Two bone-marrow transplants, years of chemo.   Mountain biking saved my life.... I took my first spin class during chemo.  Ride on, my friend.  Thank you for sharing this.  Most of my bikes have "easier than cancer" on them...my new Moots is engraved with it.
A beautiful film and a wonderful person taking what he can control on.  What more can be said really.

I was diagnosed with testicular cancer in 1993. I had radiotherapy only, so I think I was very lucky. I remember seeing the puir souls who were receiving chemo!at the Glasgow hospital I attended, sitting in their chairs with the ubiquitous drips attached to their arms.Cancer takes away choice (as Justin says), and to a certain extent dignity. Watching this man‚Äôs determination to tell cancer that he would make definitive choices every day is both humbling and inspirational. Lang may yer lum reek, Justin.
A very brave and inspiring man.

Watching this makes me happy and sad at the same time. ... sad because I always thought I have a hard time .. and I saw this and I saw That he is suffering so much.  And I am freakin happy about the Way he choose and I am happy to see him riding.  I love it.  And that‚Äôs why I love cYcling so much.  It‚Äôs a simple thing but it can change everything ‚ù§Ô∏è you are awesome ‚ù§Ô∏è

I hope a frw years later, if you come across this, well done, thumbs up and great to see you come out the other end , To anyone who reads this and is going through this pain and shit, keep it going be, I can't think how tough it must be but be strong.x.x.x.

Thank you for giving this to the world, and to me. I was diagnosed on Jan. 31 this year (2018). I rode my bike as often as possible throughout chemo. It helped a lot to be on my bike and have a sense of control and normalcy. I've felt like this experience should change me somehow but, I don't know how yet. I wish I could give something inspiring and beautiful like this short to the cancer community and to the world! Thank you!
Planning a cycle trip whilst battling cancer.. now that is grit, direction and determination. Well done Justin..
Beautiful film and story
Brilliant video... i'm so out of words,  i was so amazed watching this video with who brave and, at the same time inspiring was Justin to me ... bless you Justin

This is like the fifth time I have watched this.¬† I remember the morning I was diagnosed with Testicular cancer....so many emotions going on while trying to deal with docs ordering tests and wanting to operate NOW.¬† The physical recovery from the op and then deciding about chemo or radiation.¬† I now truly hate gingerale...the very smell sickens me, but it helped with the sickness after rad treatments.¬† Thankfully, I am now five years cancer free, and ride my bike whenever I can (which is never enough!).¬† Thank you Justin for documenting your journey.
Beautiful & inspiring <3 You're the best Justin..
Amazing story..The best short films, unbelievable..The view is just so beautiful!!!!
